March 15, 2015

The hacker that startups needs

There is a job in technology startups called “Growth Hacker”. Growth Hacker is a hacker that specializes in growing the users base of the service or the product through various tactics in development and marketing, the name hacker has nothing to do with hacking and penetrating systems and devices but it is closer to the definition of hacker who connect some things to accomplish something great.

Growth Hacker

The term “Growth Hacker” was invented by Sean Ellis through his article ” Find a growth hacker for your startup” in his article Sean challenged that all startups need someone to lead their efforts to real growth. Usually startups and small companies hire someone with experience in marketing, but as Sean says this may not be the person with the tools and knowledge who can lead startups to a real and exponential growth.  Andrew Chen took the term and he improved it and added a lot of importance to it as well as he gave an example that illustrate the important role of the growth hacker in his article ” Growth hacker is the new VP marketing” .

Andrew mentions that “growth hacker” is a mixture between marketing and developer together. So that he is trying to answer the question: How can I bring more users to my service? However, using techniques such as creating landing pages, A / B testing, virality factor, as well as the more technical stuff that test the possible ways to increase number of users, which may be related to how to develop the service, user interface, and the methods for sending mail alerts through the service, referral program to bring your friends and other tactics that often you may not expect to be done by a person with traditional marketing skills. So the experience and study of a “Growth hacker”  is based on marketing, sales, engineering and other disciplines or expertise. But in the end, he has only one clear goal GET USERS.

Growth hacking is just GET USERS! – Gary Vaynerchuk

What is the difference between a Growth Hacker and the Marketer?

Hacker growth is no better than a marketer, or an alternate at all (this point agreed upon by all the pioneers of the concept of hacker growth), but he differs from them in terms of the role and the tasks he perform, which is clearly, the growth of the service. All his decisions, strategies, methods designed for one thing: GETTING USERS. This does not mean that the marketer does not help with the growth of the service or can not do it. The difference, is that the growth hacker is specialized and dedicated only to growth. Just consider him a specialist consultant to assist you in your service growth.

By the way, this is exactly what happened to the creator of the term Sean Ellis. When (Dropbox) needed his services to grow and so a lot of other startups in Silicon Valley. Sean needed assistants to help him he found that CVs of applicants were excellent in marketing, but he knew that he needs another type of skills which made him invent the term.

When do I need a Growth Hacker ?

Perfect timing is when you find a service that solves a real problem, which means you found a suitable link between the problem and the solution provided to the market. The service is now in the beginning reaching to the market, and it proves that the market needs it and there is an increased demand for it.

Tips for anyone who is interested to be a Growth Hacker

  • Try to host meetups or look for those interested in the topic social networks or tech meetings, to share new ideas and methods.
  • Curiosity, innovation, love experiences, tracking everything new is very important characteristics in this type of work.
  • You have to develop your skills in several areas of development, user experience, follow-up statistics, marketing channels and methods and other areas that you have to master.
  • Keep monitoring the Hashtag #growthhacking.
  • Follow Growth Hacking experts Twitter, my advice is to make a list and call it something like Growth Hacking and begin to add to it who you think that he is a great in this field and that he can help you learn more such as:
  1. Sean Ellis (Eventbrite, Dropbox, Xobni, Catchfree) – Originally coined the term
  2. Noah Kagan (AppSumo, Mint, Facebook) – @noahkagan
  3. Mike Greenfield (Circle of Moms, ex LinkedIn) – @mike_greenfield
  4. Siqi Chen (ex-Zynga) – @blader
  5. Ed Baker (Facebook) – @esbaker
  6. Joe Greenstein (Flixster) – @joseph77b
  7. Yee Lee (Google) – @yeeguy
  8. Othman Laraki (Twitter) – @othman
  9. Akash Garg (Twitter, ex-Hi5) – @akashgarg
  10. Jonathan Katzman (Yahoo, ex-Xoopit) – @jkatzman
